Description: Two journalists detained after writing corona-related stroy. The story was deleted from the website, haberimizvar.net, after the journalists were released.
TK- program researching

Looks at the panic and riots that took place in Novi Sanzhary, Ukraine, largely due to a disinformation campaign related to the virus. "Looking back, residents [of the city], including doctors, said the anger and panic were stoked by the government’s decision to withhold information from them, misinformation that spread across social media, and sensational coverage by the news media.

"Pro-Kremlin media have been spreading disinformation about coronavirus with the aim of 'aggravating' the public health crisis in the west, the European Union’s diplomatic service has concluded in a leaked report." This article reviews several of the 80 examples of disinformation from Russian sources the EU Monitor recored between January 16 to March 16.

New law will permanently amend two articles of the criminal code that will further limit freedom of expression and penalize people for breaching quarantine orders. It will also suspend all elections and referendums.

Under one measure, anyone who disseminates information that could hinder the government’s response to the epidemic could face up to five years in prison. The legislation gives broad latitude to the public prosecutor to determine what counts as distorted or false information.Lawyer Daniel Karsai echoes same point as Gulnoza--this marks birth of dictatorship

İdris Özyol (chief editor) and Ebru Özaydın (editor) from the local online newspaper Haberimiz Var were detained by the police from their houses and questioned about their reporting on Coronavirus. They were released after questioning. The story in question was deleted.

Freelance journalist Aydın Atay was called by the police to be questioned about his tweet on Coronavirus (Diyarbakır Courthouse is closed due to Coronavirus). He was released after offering testimony to the police.
16 field reporters and camera personnel of the Demirören Media Group were forced to work inside a container in front of their offices as a precaution.

İsmet Çiğit (chief editor), Ahmet Seminer (responsible news editor) and Güngör Arslan (İnternet editor) from the local newspaper SES Kocaeli were detained by the police from their houses at night and questioned about their reporting on Coronavirus. They were released after questioning. The story in question was deleted.

Tugay Can, reporter for the local newspaper İz Gazete, was called by the police to be questioned about his reporting on Coronavirus (two medical workers in two different districts of Izmir tested positive). He was released after offering testimony to the police.
Interior minister said almost 2,000 social media accounts had been identified making provocative posts about the outbreak, resulting in the detention of 410 people "attempting to stir unrest."
Government media watchdog RTÜK fined three TV channels due to their reporting on Coronavirus: Halk TV, TELE1 and Habertürk.
Nurcan Baysal, writer and columnist for critical online outlet Ahval, was called to testify about her tweets on the Coronavirus pandemic. She was let go after ater questioned.
Oktay Candemir, local journalist from the eastern province of Van, was called to testify about his reporting on Coronavirus.
ministry official attacks reporter covering #coronavirus event (not clear whether related to reporting)

Reporter detained over #coronavirus article, released,
 PM apology

Government severly restricts flow of information on coronavirus, 
J-association warns of censorship
NHS staff 'gagged' over coronavirus shortages
TV crew of public broadcaster attacked
hospital put pressure on investigative journalist in coronavirus reporting

citizen journalist detained while documenting a demonstration
 under coronavirus state of emergency

journalists shortly detained and charged for allegedly not following
sanitary guidelines
J-association warns against using criminal code provisions against journalists #coronavirus
Journalists covering coronavirus  attacked by street vendors in Turin
PM verbally attacks TV crew for coronavirus reporting
newspaper reporter and photographer covering #coronavirus threatened by local
Locals attack a crew of reporters covering coronavirus

journalist verbally assaulted by municipal leader over

Investigative journalist attacked in probably government

The White House prohibited audio and video coverage of a critical briefing on coronavirus
Access. White House told federal health officials to classify coronavirus deliberations.
Harassed. Reporter yelled at while asking questions about coronavirus.
Reporters cut off repeatedly during WH briefing; President calls PBS correspondent's question "nasty"
Access. Journalist turned away from briefing following temperature screening. Not sure we should call this a press freedom violation, but good to have on here
Surgeon general tells reporters "no more finger pointing." Again, don't think we want to call this a press freedom violation, but good to track

"The day after he became the focus of sharp criticism for urging Fox News viewers to go out to their local restaurants and pubs in direct contradiction of CDC guidelines, Rep. Devin Nunes (R-CA) claimed 'media freaks' were distorting his remarks."
Change to WH briefing seating
Chiling statement. U.S. Senator Richard Burr: "In a tabloid-style hit piece today, NPR knowingly and irresponsibly misrepresented a speech I gave last month about the coronavirus threat."
The main CBC network will replace local nightly newscasts in all areas except stations in the north.

Disinformation. In a statement, Judd Deere, a White House spokesman, said that “any suggestion that President Trump did not take the threat of Covid-19 seriously or that the United States was not prepared is false.” Not directed specifically at any journalist or news organization, it seems, but nonetheless thought worth flagging given the magnitude of the problem of disinformation/misinformation in the US around things like testing and also use of 'false' label
Reporter for the Miami Herald and Tampa Bay Times not allowed into governor's press briefing on covid-19

Discusses the results of a survey that asked Americans to rate the performance of the media's coverage of coronavirus. General findings of the survey: a) "Americans give the news media fairly high marks for their coverage of COVID-19, though most think their reporting has at least somewhat exaggerated the risks"; b) "About half the public (48%) say they’ve been exposed to at least some made-up news and information related to the virus"; and, c) "substantial portions [of survey respondents] express belief in claims that are in fact false" (e.g., 29% think it was created in a lab).

Socorro has been target of coordinated state trolling. Includes a Vice-Minister sending Socorro a tweet (https://twitter.com/planwac/status/1236401422477950979?s=20) from his official account. She sent Ana Cristina all of the screen shots of the tweets. She has been a strong critic of the government, and has had her Twitter account hacked in the past.

Journalist Gregoria Diaz received insults and threats through Twitter, Instagram and WhatsApp after reporting via Twitter of a possible case of Coronavirus of a citizen from China, in the city of Maracay, on February 21. The mayor herself retweeted the campaign on social media to discredit Díaz. She has also been harassed by local officials since posting the tweet.

Jesús Enrique Torres and Jesus Manuel Castillo were detained by police on March 13.Castillo and Torres appeared before a judge in Los Teques on March 15, when they were charged with “crimes against the state” and released, according to Carlos Torres, the father of Jesús Torres, who spoke to Espacio Público but did not cite any specific laws the journalists were alleged to have broken. The journalists are required to register their whereabouts with authorities once a week as their legal case proceeds, Murolo said.
Melquiades Avila was threatened multiple times and is now in hiding.
José Benítez (+cameraman) Police detained them for allegedly violating curfew, though press workers are excluded. Relased later that same day.
Police hit Paola Cobo + other journalists documenting the moment when police are detaining invidividuals for failing to comply with curfew imposed due to Coronavirus

Two soldiers and a security guard at the CIFCO convention center stopped a TV journalist from taking photos outside the center, which is being converted to an emergency hospital for COVID-19 patients. Unnamed journalist and unidentified outlet

Beatriz Rodriguez. Police take from her home to the prosecutor's office to interrogate her on a report of a case that tested positive for Coronavirus published in the La Verdad daily, where she is the Editor. She is interrogated again on the 25. She is being pressured to reveal sources.

Rosalí Hernández, Caraota Digital. Special forces agents FAES detain her for 40 min and force her to delete the videos she had recorded showing the cleaning/ sterilization of streets ordered by the government to fight the pandemic.
Yarnaldo Tovar, 360 Grados INternacional. Detained by the national police outisde a hospital (Hopsital Pereférico de Coche), Caracas, covering coronavirus. Released several hours later.
Miguel Eduardo Taveras deatined and handcuffed by police for alleged breach of curfew, though press is exempted.
Ralph Zapata of OjoPublico detained inside his home by 10 policemen, taken to the police station.
Five journalists granted parloe after spreading disinformation relating to coronavirus
Kaka Touda Mamane Goni, detained. dissemination of data likely to disturb public order.
Fake news. Kenya arrests 23-year old aspiring blogger and influencer for peddling fake news. Unclear if he was actually pushing false narratives-- need to follow up w Africa.

"Just in that fake news/ disinformation about #COVID19 becomes a criminal offence in South Africa." Under the Disaster Management Act, section 11(4)1/: "Any person who publishes any statement, through any medium, including social media, with the intention to deceive any other person about— (a) COVID-19; (b) COVID-19 infection status of any person; or (c) any measure taken by the Government to address COVID-19, commits an offence."
Journalist Robert Alai charged with spreading false informatmion relating to coronavirus pandemic
Blogger Cyprian Nyakundi arrested by police over post made about coronavirus on social media
Members of church attack journalists who were monitoring restrictions on movement relating to coronavirus

TV reporter Tholi Totali Glody was run down by police in Likasi. Glody works for one of Likasi's leading TV stations, Alfajari TV, whose programme director told RSF that, after explaining to two policemen that he was covering respect for the lockdown, Glody was chased by the police and knocked off the motorcycle, breaking a leg and sustaining injuries to his face and an arm.

Not mandate but worrying. Two people (Husband and wife I think), Boniface Elias Mwita and Rosemary Elias Mwita, were arrested in Dar es Salaam and are now facing charges of spreading false news about Coronavirus. According to a post on Jamii Forums, while riding in a public transport minibus (dala dala) from Tabata to Muhibili Hospital in Dar es Salaam, the two were heard by fellow passengers claiming that Coronavirus is a hoax, and alleged that the reason schools were closed is because the govt does not have money to feed students in school, and that the government just wants foreign aid. The fellow passengers in the dala dala, after listening to the “fake news”, ordered the driver to drive to a police station, where the two Mwitas were arrested. Investigations into the case are over, and the file has been submitted to prosecutors.
David Njagi Freelance
Link: Muthoki Conversation on March 24 with Winnie Kamau (+721754349) of the Kenya Freelancers Association.

Description: Outlets denied access to Aso Rock. over 80 journalists

Yayesew Shimelis, a journalist with the state-owned Tigray TV who also contributes to a column to the Feteh Magazine and runs his own YouTube channel was arrested today on allegations of false news in connection to COVID19. According to tweets by @befeqe and private conversation between CPJ and two other sources, he was arrested in connection to a video posted yesterday in which he claimed that religious leaders in Ethiopia have been ordered to prepare 200,000 graves for expected COVID19 deaths. Earlier today, before Yayesew’s arrest, the ruling party in the Tigray bureau of the ruling prosperity party is said to have issued a press statement today calling for legal measures against those who spread false news and cause panic, and specifically cited Yayesew. They also called out another journalist by name, Tigray TV’s Medhin Gebreselassie, who is said to have claimed that 300,000 people would die in the Tigray region from the coronavirus. Yayesew apologise for the video, which has been taken down already, in a tweet today, according to @befeqe. I suggest for now we just retweet Befekadu. Our advocacy ask needs to be nuanced and I want to listen to the video before I come up with it.

An NTV Cameraperson, Peter Wainaina, was today afternoon assaulted by police in Mombasa Kenya who were trying to get people off the streets ahead of the 7pm curfew. In the video shared by NTV Kenya on its handle, Wainaina can be heard saying: “its not 6PM yet”. The police officer tells him, “I have forgiven you, you’re like my brother”, says something about throwing stones and claims that they can’t wait for 6PM. But even if it was after curfew, the government of Kenya has declared media( licensed broadcasters and media houses) part of the essential personnel that are allowed to be out and about at night.
State governor, Wike sacks journalists including Vincent Ake for story on COVID-19
Angela Nkwo Akpolu manhandled, phone seized for snapping quarantine centers
Restricted movement: Journalists need ID cards to move around during lockdown
Regulation that criminalizes spreading falsehood on coronovirus subject to a 20 year jaril term or a hefty fine or both

Kudzanai Musengi. Practicing as a journalist without vald accreditation while photographin lockdwon effects.  But Zim Media Commission in January authorized jorunalists to continue working using their 2029 accreditaiton until further notice. New fees and accresitiatoin notice only issue on  MArch 27
Tatenda Julius,  Arrested for practising as a journo without valid accredition and detained overnight. Paid a fine next day and was released/

Disaster Management Regulations criminalizes the publishing of any statement, through any memida, including social media, with the intention to decidve any other paerson aobut COVID-19, the infection status of any person or any measure taken by the government to address COVID-19, lialbe on conviction to a fine or 6 months in jail or both

Policeman deliberately fires at Azarrah Karrim with rubber bullets. Journaiist was filming Day of the lockdown when police forcibly dispered shoppers queing at a supremarket for food. Police dispersed the shoppers and chased after them. One policeman saw here filming and shot at her, despite her shouting she was a journalist and then chased her into a restaurant, where two of his colleagues intervened. She has laid a charge and complained to IPID
Link: https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/police-clash-with-joburg-residents-news24-reporter-caught-in-crossfire-20200327 AQ spoke to journo herself who sent a recording of what happened to her that is a lot jore serious than what appeas in this article

Description: Prime TV suspended and taken off Top Star platform after owner tells government to pay for Coronvirus adverts
This heavy-handed policeman confiscates #photographer Tracey Adam's cell as she takes footage of an assault in Capricorn Park.
Journalist infected, newsroom SABC goes into quarantine
Samuel Wazizi habeus corupus postponed. Defence and state lawyers fail to appear in court because of conflicting information about court closing over COVID-19

Description: Makes u-trun on previous day decision that court sessions cancelled, now no more than 50 -people in court. Concern about more dealys for awating trial journos and appeals, etc,
Cellphone companies agree to hand over location date to government for COVID tracking
Economic effects of small publications like M&G. Editor appeals for financial help because of effects of the pandemic on adverstising revenue, etc, and that theu can't pay staff or billls
Another employee based at SABC HQ found tested and confirmed coronvirus case
Information minister says Journalists need ID cards to move around in Lockdown
Press Union makes uregent request for financial assistance, says many media may have to suspend work, following economic meltdown and effects of COVID-19
Frank Payne flogged. Press Union of Liberia Condemned Payne's follogging, on oders of LDEA boss after the journalist tried to report none-compliance of social disnce regulations

During a press conference to provide updates on the Coronavirus, the Chief Administrative Secretary from the ministry of health refused to take questions from the media. There is speculation that they did not want to be asked about a 13 year old boy who was killed by a “stray” bullet from police who were enforcing a curfew on March 30.

Gregory Murithi, a cameraman with Weru TV, was assaulted by police officers on March 28, 2020 at Mitunguu market in Imenti South district, Meru County. Murithi was recording local officials forcefully evicting traders, assaulting market women, and scattering their wares while claiming to be enforcing social distancing measures at the market. One of the police officers tried to take away his camera, they ordered the journalist to delete footage, but he stood his ground. The journalist reported the matter at Mitunguu police station, but according to Nairobi news he was kept waiting for two hours before police recorded the incident in the OB (Occurrence Book).

John Kiarie (an MP). Not sure this would be mandate. A member of parliament, John Kiarie, was summoned yesterday by police and questioned about a Facebook post in which he claimed that there were 7,000 kenyans in quarantine, who had arrived back in the country between Wednesday and Sunday last week. The MP also said that the country has limited testing capacity, and that the government is communicating low estimates. He further estimated that by May Kenya will have at least 10,000 cases of COVID19. He then called on the government to communicate the real gravity of the situation, start establishing isolation centres around the country, mass produce masks and ventilators etc. He was released after he agreed to issue a clarification on his “alarming post” His clarification includes him saying the he based the figure of 10,000 on a scientific study. On March 30, the minister of health, who had earlier publicly condemned the MP for his comments, told a press conference that preliminary modelling indicated that Kenya would have about 5,000 to 10,000 cases of COVID19 by mid-April, absent drastic intervention.
Police dispersed several newspaper vendors and arrested four for violating the presidential directive for national lockdown.

Two journalists Khaya Koko & Sesona Ngqakamba were covering a police brutality case w.r.t the lockdown. Some of the officers' colleagues, who appeared to have been drinking, became very aggressive towards the two jouranlists.

A local pastor, Augustine Yiga, was arrested in connection to comments he made to the media about COVID19. The ministry of health asked police to arrest a pastor, Augustine Yiga, who in tv broadcast called the Coronavirus pandemic a hoax. Today (March 30) morning he was remanded to prison after being charged with spreading harmful propaganda. Prosecution claims that he knew or had reason to believe that his comments were likely to spread COVID19, according to the Daily Monitor. The ministry also wants the Uganda Communications Commission to take action against the pastor and his radio station, ABS.

This one is connected to the above incident of Pastor Yiga, PML Daily reports that the Uganda Communications Commission has written to three tv stations asking them to show cause why regulatory sanctions shouldn’t be taken against them, in connection to their coverage of COVID19. The stations, BBS TV, NTV and Spark TV could also face criminal charges of actions “likely to spread infection of any disease” for which those convicted could face up to 7 years in prison. According to PML Daily, the UCC accuses the stations of airing content with the potential “to confuse, divert and mislead” the public. The allegations against BBS and Spark tv arise from the stations having broadcasted Pastor Yiga’s comments that COVID19 is a hoax. NTV is accused of giving a platform to one Simon Senyonga on march 26, who is said to have made “objectionable” comments about COVID 19. I am trying to second-source this since it does not seem that NTV, BBS or Spark TV are reporting this.
Required to carry press cards to move around
E.O of GNN asked to provide source of story about COVID-19
Kaizolo was attacked by  LDEA officials while covering live, attempts by police to clear marketers in Liberia's COVID-19 response
NCDC, partners Premium Times, Africa check to check fake news on COVID-19

The justice system accused the two newspapers of having published a statement from the group of lawyers for an Ivorian opposition MP, Alain Lobognon, arrested and imprisoned at the end of December for complicity in a supposed attempt at “insurrection”. The lawyers were concerned about the conditions of incarceration in the context of the coronavirus pandemic and requested the release of their client.
Mostafa Faghihi/ Journalist / charged under Iran penal code for spreading lies relating to coronavirus
Journalist Fardin Mostafaei / arrested/ interrogated on charges of spreading misinformation/ false news relating to coronavirus under the Iran Penal code.
A group of Kurdish journalists charged (?) with disinformation (can we say fake news or no?)
150 citizen journlaists and social media users who were informing the public were arrested

Tehran Prosecutor General Ali Alghasi-Mehr had issued an order saying, “in order to manage public opinion and the media, the judiciary will identify, document, and summon those who spread false news through various news websites, social media channels, such as Instagram, and other news sources in the shortest time possible.”
Iran's parliament announced any one who spreads False News about Coronavirus will be sentenced to 3 years in prison. (They see any coverage of the virus as False News anyway!!)
Arrested at least 24 people who were informing the public on social media by sharing news about coronavirus. Citizen jouranlists? Imprisoned? Fake News?

Abdollah Seyed Ahmadi Zavieh,  editor of the state-run Fars news agency, passed away after contracting COVID 19 . Noteworthy given how bad the outbreak has been there plus Iranian government's contradictory positions on dangers faced by media workers, including the fact they do not consider them essential workers and thus do not offer them extra health protections

At least 19 Iranian journalists who work for the state's main broadcasting the Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting (IRIB) are infected with the virus. Most were infected while covering February election. Iranian journalists are not considered essential workers so they are not provided PPE that other front line workers have access to.
Gov't revokes press credentials for Ruth Michaelson and threatens NYTimes reporter Declan Walsh
an emergency “defense law” gave wide latitude to Prime Minister Omar Razzaz, who said his government would “deal firmly” with anyone who spreads “rumors, fabrications and false news that sows panic.”
Coronavirus Combat Taskforce banned all print media. The ban will be in place as long as coronavirus-related restrictions are in effect.

Report on the findings of "ProPublica’s research [that] tracked how the government-linked influence accounts that had targeted political dissidents and the Hong Kong protests turned their focus to the coronavirus outbreak. During the height of the epidemic in China, many of [these accounts] became cheerleaders for the government, calling on citizens to unite in support of efforts to fight the epidemic and urging them to 'dispel online rumors.' With the epidemic spreading across the world, these accounts have sought to promote the Chinese government’s image abroad and shore up its support at home."

The "last-minute amendment to President Rodrigo Duterte's special powers bill to contain the novel coronavirus was an expansion of the section on penalties, which now specifically punishes the spreading of fake and alarming information by up 2 months in prison and up to P1 million in fines. [...] Former Supreme Court spokesperson Ted Te said the subparagraph on the punishment of fake news: "'since there is no law that criminizalizes or defines fake news as a crime, and the special powers law does not also define what fake news is, it cannot be criminalized. That would be void.'"

4 people in Taiwan were charged with violating the Social Order Maintenance Act and the Criminal Codes by spreading rumors about the epidemic online. The contents they posted were conspiracy theories about the Taiwanese government stockpiling surgical masks for the rich. So far, no journalists affected.

Discusses the Taiwanese government's efforts to deal with disinformation in relation to the virus, ranging from press releases to new legislation. "According to Taiwan’s Special Act on COVID-19 Prevention, Relief, and Restoration passed on Feb. 25, individuals who spread rumors or disinformation about COVID-19 that risk harming the public interest can face a maximum prison term of three years and a possible fine of NT$3 million (US$99,000)."
Criminalization: type of new or amended: Special Act on COVID-19 Prevention, Relief, and Restoration

Description: Government uses false news law to order STR to correct false statements it made on government adhering to WHO guidelines . This raises question of whether it is acceptable for a governemnt to make decisions about what information can be taken down, when that information is in fact blatantly false as in this case.

Government files three criminal charges against journalist Wan Noor Hayati Wan Alias under penal code Section 505(b) for causing “fear or alarm to the public” or “commit an offense against the State or public tranquility” over three coronavirus related tweets. Trial ongoing; she faces a possible six years in prison
Aajtak journalist Naveen Kumar was beaten up by police on his way to work
Jansandesh Times report Vijay Kumar Singh was beaten up by police on his way to work
Link: Copy of police complaint with Kunal

Description: Police in Hyderabad also beat and insulted Mendu Srinivas, political bureau chief of Telugu-language daily Andhra Jyothy,  for alleged lockdown violations while he was returning from work
Police in Hyderabad hit Mohammed Hussain, a reporter for the English news website Siasat, for alleged lockdown violations while he was returning from work

"Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha said today that the worst thing about the ongoing novel coronavirus situation in Thailand is panic caused by fake news, as he warned those with ill-intent that they will be dealt with decisively and in accordance with the law."

Thai sports reporter Noppadol Sritaweekard is first reported member of Thai media to contract Covid-19. He was infected while covering a boxing event that has emerged as a major cluster of infections in the country.
ETV deputy news editor Uttkarsh Chaturvedi was beaten up by the police while reporting on the locknown in Thane district in Maharashtra, despite showing his press card

KK Saxena became the first Indian journalist to be infected by COVID19. He got the virus from his daughter who returned from the UK.  He had attended two press conferences just before he was tested positive. A case of "negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life" have been filed against him by Bhopal police because he attended two important press conferences even though his daughter was quarantined
Varanasi district magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma sent a legal notice to Jansandesh Time over an article claimed some villager had nothing to eat due to lockdown.

The Information Ministry announced that it has formed a unit to monitor social media and various television outlets for “rumors” about COVID-19 cases. So far, no reports of journalists, but the authorities have apparently arrested at least a dozen people, including a doctor, opposition activists, and students, for their comments about coronavirus, most of them under the draconian Digital Security Act.
Criminalization: type of new or amended: new unit to monitor social media, use of Digital Security Act

Description: Officials of bthe Delta state tax force attacked journalists, Micheal Ikeogu and Mathew Omonigho while they monitored the level of complaionce to stay-at-home directives for their report
Journalist, Charles Yates Interrogated by NSA for social mefdia post alleging corruption from government in the implementation of health strategies to curb COVID-19
